notes: 700 Series (1982-1992) including 740 and 760 variants. Replaced 240 at upper end of range. Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 gasoline/turbo, PRV V6, or diesel engines. 760 featured PRV V6 and more luxury appointments. Available as sedan and wagon. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 700 Series article, January 2025 revision.

480 sports coupe (1986-1995). Volvo's first front-wheel drive car and first hatchback. Based on Mitsubishi platform with Renault engines. 3-door shooting brake/hatchback design. Not officially sold in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 480 article, January 2025 revision.

780 luxury coupe (1985-1990). Two-door coupe based on 760 platform, designed and built by Bertone in Italy. PRV V6 or turbocharged inline-4 engines. Rear-wheel drive. Limited production luxury coupe. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 780 article, January 2025 revision.

940 sedan/wagon (1990-1998). Evolution of 740, part of 900 Series. Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 gasoline, turbo, or diesel engines. Known for reliability and safety. Available as sedan and wagon. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 940 article, January 2025 revision.

960 sedan/wagon (1990-1998). Flagship model replacing 760, part of 900 Series. Inline-6 engines, rear-wheel drive. More luxurious than 940. Later renamed S90/V90 in 1996. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 960 article, January 2025 revision.

240 Series (1974-1993, 1980s coverage). Iconic boxy Volvo design with rear-wheel drive. Inline-4 gasoline, turbo, or diesel engines. Renowned for safety and durability. Available as 2-door, 4-door sedan, and wagon. Production continued through 1993. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 200 Series article, January 2025 revision.
